sure, but they were not made by the faculty.
Scholars, indeed, must attend lectures at least
three times a week, but if a professor wished
to be absent for a single day, he must first get
the consent of his pupils, then ask permission
of the Rector and the heads of nations. If
going out of town, he must leave a deposit to
secure his return. He could not create holidays
to suit himself, and the students were, on their
part, bound by oath to report any master who
was unfaithful. The burden of punctuality
also lay with the professor. He must begin
at a certain hour, or pay a fine. He must stop
at a given bell; and to make sure of this the
students were bound to leave the room at
once, and fined if they did not.
In those days of few books, it was important that lecturers should complete the subjects
undertaken. Texts of the civil or canon law
were, therefore, divided up into sections or
puncta, and adjusted to a time schedule. The
professor must reach a given punctum at the
specified time or be subject to a fine for every
day in arrears. No skipping of chapters was
allowed to make up time, for there was a committee of students known as "Denunciatores
Doctorunt," who were appointed by the Rector
to take note of delinquencies. As the professor had been obliged to deposit iio with
a banker at the beginning of the year as security for good conduct, the fines were deducted
from this "caution money." Lectures by dictation still survive, but in these days of many
books and infinite material, the professor
should be fined for using medimval methods.
In the thirteenth century, university professors, as well as private school teachers, were
dependent on the fees paid them directly by
the students, and sometimes had to haggle
over the price of their wares. One or more
students were employed as negotiators with
the class, and when the attendance was large
it was possible to obtain club rates. A reminder of these mediators still remains in German universities in the "famulus" who carries the class books to be signed and does other
small services for the professor. Stated sala-

ries paid by city or state authorities came
slowly into use as means to induce professors
to settle in a new place. In the fifteenth century such stipends had fully become customary in Bologna, but the system of fines also
continued. The lecturer was even fined if he
failed to draw students. For every day that
there were less than five hearers at his class
he had to pay thirty shillings out of every
hundred of his salary. There were also fines
for short lectures and absences. A document
in the printed archives of Bologna states that
in 1470 a learned doctor was charged £84 in
fines or "punctationes," because on fourteen
different days he failed to attract as many as
five students.
At one time the professors were so much in
the hands of the students that they were
obliged to submit to an annual election by
their pupils, but this power gradually fell into
the hands of the State authorities which paid
the salaries.
There were certain conveniences about the
inedixval university which are worthy of
note. Having no buildings to leave, nor any
academic quadrangles to regret, the school
could move to a new place without the sacrifice of its plant." If the municipal authorities were uncivil to students, or refused to pay
sufficient stipends to professors, the whole
body could refuse to work, or migrate to a
more favorable city. This happened frequently, and several of the most important
universities were founded by academic seceders.
Universities were not all governed on the
plan of Bologna. The organization of Paris
was based on a society of teachers, and Oxford
and many others followed that system. But
in all of them the student is a prominent figure, and the division into nations finds a place
under all of the forms of government. At all
places immunity from the local police was the
privilege of the scholar, and this independence
of any but academic regulations was a great
attraction to the youth of that day. Large
numbers of students wandered from one

they went in search of new men and new adventures. If the resources of learning in the
Middle Ages seem circumscribed to us, there
were wide limits to the gaieties. In Paris it
was ruled that students should not wear swords
in the university meetings, for bloody conflicts

somehow the student university failed to meet
even the inedimval requirements of discipline,
and the plan was given up over three hundred

THE EASTER TRIP.

To the freshman who has never tried to race
his fingers up and down a banjo neck, and to
the graduate who "knows it all," the ease
with which the University Banjo Club dashes
off a smashing, swinging march, and the perfect tone-shedding and self-restraint of the
Glee and Mandolin Clubs' songs and waltzes,
seems an easily acquired perfection. When
the man who is not on the Club hears of the
joys of the " Easter trip," he says the Club
men have a gold-bound snap. But he does not
know the long Tuesday evenings, and afternoons, and Saturday mornings of practice and
rehearsal, when even the perfect patience of
Peters gives out, and defeat seems to stare
the Club in the face. But all this work meets
its reward in the Easter trip, and in the maze
of old Fortress Monroe and the Richmond
german all the bitter memories of practice disappear, and the long self-sacrifice meets its full
reward.
The Easter trip of this season has surpassed
any of its illustriouS predecessors. Good management, good leaders, good clubs—have all

Now that the spring games are on, a
word upon the adequate support of Hopkins'
teams is in season. It is a time-honored subject, more's the pity, and there is nothing new
under the sun to be said about it. The most
we can do is to say again what has been said
so many times before. There may be virtue
in its repetition.
It takes money to run teams; outfits,
grounds, rubbers, traveling expenses—all
these are items on the bill, and guarantees
must be given to visiting contestants. The
locker fund is, indeed, a great boon to our
athletics, but we have had occasion to hear
more than once this winter that it is insufficient
to meet the needs of our expanding interests.
Gate receipts are still a factor in the problem
of support. The card of admission must be
reckoned with. This is the end of the first
lesson : Let us see that our teams do not
suffer for financial backing, keep a sweet temper when we are next approached with a ticket
for "Saturday's game," and pay the price with
a fine sense of loyalty.

BUT there is an equally important consideration : The inspiration to our teams, the
winning pace, that a rollicking crowd of root-

ers can give. Every mother's son of us is
human; we all can stand encouragement now
and then, nay more—need it, and right badly
do we need it, when the game, whether of life
or at ball, is going the wrong way. When our
troops were in the trenches before Santiago a
sweltering evening last July, brave men dispirited by fatigue, hunger and anxiety, the
bands along the line struck up a national air.
It meant new life, and hope, and power for
our fighters at the front. And so a rousing
"Hullabaloo I" with a rattling "Rah, Johnny " can do a good deal for the Black and
Blue, as was done for the Red, White and
Blue, on our more peaceful but as momentous
conflicts on the athletic field. Bring up your
band of rooters. This, then, is the end of the
second lesson: Go to the games, and go to
root!

OF COURSE, the teams have a hand in the
matter. If they seek the support of the University, they must give us good, clean and
earnest exhibitions, the best work of which
they are capable, whatever the sport. This is
all we can expect. This much we do expect,
and have a right to exact. There is no excuse
for "ragged bail" or "ragged" work of any
kind. " Ragged" play means careless play.
Nothing will so quickly kill a crowd. And,
furthermore, the conduct of the teams must
be thoroughly sportsmanlike. Last year, notably on the ball team, there were several instances, unpleasant to recall, that cast odium,
not only on the men concerned, but the management that permitted such unsportsmanlike
conduct on the field. It is a bad way to encourage attendance at the games. And this is
the conclusion : We do not expect our teams
to win all the time; we do expect them to give
us good, clean sport, and make us no occasion
for apologies in their behalf, and for staying
away from the games.

The season for active outdoor athletics has
now begun in earnest, and for the next six
weeks we shall do our best to bring home
some laurels in the way of victories of brawn,
as we have already repeatedly done in the way
of victories of brain.
The baseball team was first upon the field.
The prospects seemed so much brighter than
they had for several years past that Captain
Joyner and Manager Swaine determined to
attempt something a little more ambitious than
the ordinary programme of events.
They,
therefore, arranged the game with Princeton,
which was played at Union Park on March 30.
This game was looked forward to with a
great deal of interest, and, though no one
expected anything but an overwhelming defeat at the hands of the Tigers, yet it was
thought that any creditable showing at all
would be an honor to Hopkins and an encouragement to the men.
It is hard, now that the game is over and
past, to give a fitting description of the contest, or to tell just what were the feelings of
our loyal rooters after the last inning had
been played and the crowd had dispersed.
Anxiety was the primary emotion as Hopkins
went to the bat in the first inning, but as time
passed, and the Tigers' only score was 2 to our
o a feeling of confidence ensued. If this score
could only be maintained. with, perhaps, a
few runs of our own, for three more innings,
what a splendid showing it would be for us,
and what a check to the aspirations of the
proud Princetonians.
Our men seemed to be getting their share
of the hits, and, had it not been for a little
stupid coaching and poor base-running in the
first inning, there is no reason why a run or
two might not have been scored then. The
one great defect in our playing was the rattled
condition of most of the infield—old players,
too, whom one would not expect to be so affected.
Let us hope that the name and fame of those
of the smaller Maryland colleges against which

we shall play will not have such a terrifying
effect upon our fielders.
Some apprehension was felt as to the expediency of opposing to the Orange and Black
batsmen our youngest pitcher, who was comparatively inexperienced. But all fears were
set at rest by the perfect coolness and control
which he exhibited, and the manner in which
he kept his head in critical situations brought
forth frequent applause from the spectators.
His pitching, with the fine catching of Radcliffe, was, indeed, the star work of the afternoon. It really seemed as though the new
men were cool, and that the older players were
showing the nervousness.
At the beginning of the sixth inning, the
score stood 3 to o. Here the Black and Blue
went to pieces, and by means of a few wellplaced hits, together with some awful fielding
by Hopkins, the Princetonians piled up eight
runs. In the next inning two more came, and
we began to feel a pang of bitter disappointment. Twelve to nothing ! 0! for a few
runs to save a shut-out 1
Now came a specimen of really good playing by the home team. Radcliffe made a twobagger, the best hit of the game, and it would
be disgraceful if he were not allowed to get
home now. Griffin next made a fine sacrifice
to first, sending Radcliffe to third. All depended on Swainc now, and he responded
nobly with a pretty grounder that brought
Radcliffe home with the only run of the game.
Taken as a whole, the result was encouraging, for it was better than was expected but,
after the fine showing for the first six innings,
the final let-up was disappointing.
The score (12 to 1) does not accurately
show the general run of the game, which was
much less one-sided than might be imagined.
Princeton made seven hits to our six, which
was not at all bad for our side. Errors were
what did the business.
The game showed the effects of our lack of
coaching and outdoor training. If our infield
will brace up a little, and our outfield learn to
judge long flies a little better, we can look for
some good results before the season closes.

LACROSSE WITH COLUMBIA. •

The first game of our hoped-for second
championship season has been played and won,
and there is no reason why every Hopkins man
should not feel delighted with the result of the
game, especially so when it is recollected that
there were six new men on the team.
The game was called at four o'clock. One

from this "caution money." Lectures by dictation still survive, but in these days of many
books and infinite material, the professor
should be fined for using medimval methods.
In the thirteenth century, university professors, as well as private school teachers, were
dependent on the fees paid them directly by
the students, and sometimes had to haggle
over the price of their wares. One or more
students were employed as negotiators with
the class, and when the attendance was large
it was possible to obtain club rates. A reminder of these mediators still remains in German universities in the "famulus" who carries the class books to be signed and does other
small services for the professor. Stated sala-

ries paid by city or state authorities came
slowly into use as means to induce professors
to settle in a new place. In the fifteenth century such stipends had fully become customary in Bologna, but the system of fines also
continued. The lecturer was even fined if he
failed to draw students. For every day that
there were less than five hearers at his class
he had to pay thirty shillings out of every
hundred of his salary. There were also fines
for short lectures and absences. A document
in the printed archives of Bologna states that
in 1470 a learned doctor was charged £84 in
fines or "punctationes," because on fourteen
different days he failed to attract as many as
five students.
At one time the professors were so much in
the hands of the students that they were
obliged to submit to an annual election by
their pupils, but this power gradually fell into
the hands of the State authorities which paid
the salaries.
There were certain conveniences about the
inedixval university which are worthy of
note. Having no buildings to leave, nor any
academic quadrangles to regret, the school
could move to a new place without the sacrifice of its plant." If the municipal authorities were uncivil to students, or refused to pay
sufficient stipends to professors, the whole
body could refuse to work, or migrate to a
more favorable city. This happened frequently, and several of the most important
universities were founded by academic seceders.
Universities were not all governed on the
plan of Bologna. The organization of Paris
was based on a society of teachers, and Oxford
and many others followed that system. But
in all of them the student is a prominent figure, and the division into nations finds a place
under all of the forms of government. At all
places immunity from the local police was the
privilege of the scholar, and this independence
of any but academic regulations was a great
attraction to the youth of that day. Large
numbers of students wandered from one

school to another, often begging their way as
they went in search of new men and new adventures. If the resources of learning in the
Middle Ages seem circumscribed to us, there
were wide limits to the gaieties. In Paris it
was ruled that students should not wear swords
in the university meetings, for bloody conflicts
between factions or with towns-people were
only too frequent. At Oxford the inhabitants
were in actual subjection to the academic population. At Bologna, where the students governed ,themselves under the co-operative system one might have expected good order, but
somehow the student university failed to meet
even the inedimval requirements of discipline,
and the plan was given up over three hundred
years ago.

Now that the spring games are on, a
word upon the adequate support of Hopkins'
teams is in season. It is a time-honored subject, more's the pity, and there is nothing new
under the sun to be said about it. The most
we can do is to say again what has been said
so many times before. There may be virtue
in its repetition.
It takes money to run teams; outfits,
grounds, rubbers, traveling expenses—all
these are items on the bill, and guarantees
must be given to visiting contestants. The
locker fund is, indeed, a great boon to our
athletics, but we have had occasion to hear
more than once this winter that it is insufficient
to meet the needs of our expanding interests.
Gate receipts are still a factor in the problem
of support. The card of admission must be
reckoned with. This is the end of the first
lesson : Let us see that our teams do not
suffer for financial backing, keep a sweet temper when we are next approached with a ticket
for "Saturday's game," and pay the price with
a fine sense of loyalty.

BUT there is an equally important consideration : The inspiration to our teams, the
winning pace, that a rollicking crowd of root-

ers can give. Every mother's son of us is
human; we all can stand encouragement now
and then, nay more—need it, and right badly
do we need it, when the game, whether of life
or at ball, is going the wrong way. When our
troops were in the trenches before Santiago a
sweltering evening last July, brave men dispirited by fatigue, hunger and anxiety, the
bands along the line struck up a national air.
It meant new life, and hope, and power for
our fighters at the front. And so a rousing
"Hullabaloo I" with a rattling "Rah, Johnny " can do a good deal for the Black and
Blue, as was done for the Red, White and
Blue, on our more peaceful but as momentous
conflicts on the athletic field. Bring up your
band of rooters. This, then, is the end of the
second lesson: Go to the games, and go to
root!

OF COURSE, the teams have a hand in the
matter. If they seek the support of the University, they must give us good, clean and
earnest exhibitions, the best work of which
they are capable, whatever the sport. This is
all we can expect. This much we do expect,
and have a right to exact. There is no excuse
for "ragged bail" or "ragged" work of any
kind. " Ragged" play means careless play.
Nothing will so quickly kill a crowd. And,
furthermore, the conduct of the teams must
be thoroughly sportsmanlike. Last year, notably on the ball team, there were several instances, unpleasant to recall, that cast odium,
not only on the men concerned, but the management that permitted such unsportsmanlike
conduct on the field. It is a bad way to encourage attendance at the games. And this is
the conclusion : We do not expect our teams
to win all the time; we do expect them to give
us good, clean sport, and make us no occasion
for apologies in their behalf, and for staying
away from the games.

The season for active outdoor athletics has
now begun in earnest, and for the next six
weeks we shall do our best to bring home
some laurels in the way of victories of brawn,
as we have already repeatedly done in the way
of victories of brain.
The baseball team was first upon the field.
The prospects seemed so much brighter than
they had for several years past that Captain
Joyner and Manager Swaine determined to
attempt something a little more ambitious than
the ordinary programme of events.
They,
therefore, arranged the game with Princeton,
which was played at Union Park on March 30.
This game was looked forward to with a
great deal of interest, and, though no one
expected anything but an overwhelming defeat at the hands of the Tigers, yet it was
thought that any creditable showing at all
would be an honor to Hopkins and an encouragement to the men.
It is hard, now that the game is over and
past, to give a fitting description of the contest, or to tell just what were the feelings of
our loyal rooters after the last inning had
been played and the crowd had dispersed.
Anxiety was the primary emotion as Hopkins
went to the bat in the first inning, but as time
passed, and the Tigers' only score was 2 to our
o a feeling of confidence ensued. If this score
could only be maintained. with, perhaps, a
few runs of our own, for three more innings,
what a splendid showing it would be for us,
and what a check to the aspirations of the
proud Princetonians.
Our men seemed to be getting their share
of the hits, and, had it not been for a little
stupid coaching and poor base-running in the
first inning, there is no reason why a run or
two might not have been scored then. The
one great defect in our playing was the rattled
condition of most of the infield—old players,
too, whom one would not expect to be so affected.
Let us hope that the name and fame of those
of the smaller Maryland colleges against which

we shall play will not have such a terrifying
effect upon our fielders.
Some apprehension was felt as to the expediency of opposing to the Orange and Black
batsmen our youngest pitcher, who was comparatively inexperienced. But all fears were
set at rest by the perfect coolness and control
which he exhibited, and the manner in which
he kept his head in critical situations brought
forth frequent applause from the spectators.
His pitching, with the fine catching of Radcliffe, was, indeed, the star work of the afternoon. It really seemed as though the new
men were cool, and that the older players were
showing the nervousness.
At the beginning of the sixth inning, the
score stood 3 to o. Here the Black and Blue
went to pieces, and by means of a few wellplaced hits, together with some awful fielding
by Hopkins, the Princetonians piled up eight
runs. In the next inning two more came, and
we began to feel a pang of bitter disappointment. Twelve to nothing ! 0! for a few
runs to save a shut-out 1
Now came a specimen of really good playing by the home team. Radcliffe made a twobagger, the best hit of the game, and it would
be disgraceful if he were not allowed to get
home now. Griffin next made a fine sacrifice
to first, sending Radcliffe to third. All depended on Swainc now, and he responded
nobly with a pretty grounder that brought
Radcliffe home with the only run of the game.
Taken as a whole, the result was encouraging, for it was better than was expected but,
after the fine showing for the first six innings,
the final let-up was disappointing.
The score (12 to 1) does not accurately
show the general run of the game, which was
much less one-sided than might be imagined.
Princeton made seven hits to our six, which
was not at all bad for our side. Errors were
what did the business.
The game showed the effects of our lack of
coaching and outdoor training. If our infield
will brace up a little, and our outfield learn to
judge long flies a little better, we can look for
some good results before the season closes.

The first game of our hoped-for second
championship season has been played and won,
and there is no reason why every Hopkins man
should not feel delighted with the result of the
game, especially so when it is recollected that
there were six new men on the team.
The game was called at four o'clock. One
minute after the ball had been faced, after a
pretty catch, it was shot through Columbia's
goal. Twice again did they repeat this trick,
and then, after a couple of lightning Hopkins
passes, Covert shot a goal for Columbia. When
time was called, Hopkins led by four goals
to one.
In the second half both teams played hard.
Our men seemed very much fagged out at
times. This, however, was probably due to the
mistake of asking the team to travel two hundred miles and play the game one hour later.
Columbia at times played desperately, but were
hindered from scoring by the magnificent work
of Guggenheimer, who seems to be in rare
form this season.
Maddren played his old star game, and by his
brilliant work showed that he is one of the
mainstays on the defense ; he should not aspire
to play on the attack. Griffin, Tyler and Bruton did very well for green men, but they
should not neglect to practice. Jones, with his
familiar old slash and telling body-check, was
very much in evidence. It is a pity that Abercrombie was not feeling his best, for although
he played his position very well, his work did
not follow the pace he set in last year's Lehigh
game. Fitzgerald played a magnificent game,
especially in the first half, and the same may be
said of Grimes. As was aptly remarked by a
Columbia man: "McInnes is the best in-home
in the business," and his score of four goals
tells the tale. Preston, although good behind
goal, should practice catching tips, as he missed
too many passes at critical moments. Sayler,
though really a defense man, played a very
good game, and made a brilliant play in the
second half by scoring a difficult goal.

should hope that the good work may be kept
